title-group.article-title: Dynamic Labral Shear Test in Diagnosis of SLAP Lesions: Letter to the Editor

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

body.p: We read with interest the Clinical Sports Medicine Update by Knesek et al6 on diagnosis and management of superior labral anterior posterior (SLAP) tears in throwing athletes. We congratulate the authors on this detailed review and feel that it will benefit clinicians who are evaluating and treating this complex injury. However, one of the references cited by the authors in the paper contains errors that may decrease the clinician’s abilities in this area.

In their review of the physical examination testing for SLAP tears, Knesek et al make reference to a recent article by Cook et al,2 who concluded that the 5 tests they evaluated “provided minimal or no value in the diagnosis of SLAP lesions . . . further illustrating the challenge” of making the diagnosis. There are 2 discrepancies in the Cook et al paper regarding the Dynamic Labral Shear (DLS) and modified DLS (M-DLS) tests that weaken their conclusions regarding the information that can be obtained by performing these tests. These errors have been discussed in letters to the editor of the Journal of Shoulder and Elbow Surgery (JSES)4,7 and have been the subject of an erratum discussion2 and a reply.3 We would like to emphasize these points to the readers of AJSM, especially since the letters and responses are only in the online version of JSES.

The first error is that Cook et al2 reported the wrong data regarding the clinical utility of the M-DLS when they reviewed the data from the paper by Kibler et al.5 The actual clinical utility values from this level 1 study were quite good, with a likelihood ratio of 31.57. This would indicate a completely different conclusion, confirmed in the Cook et al erratum reply, which suggests that there are clinical testing methods that can aid the diagnostic process, but the Kibler et al5 paper was not specifically referenced by Knesek et al.6

The second error was that the written descriptions, the mechanics, and the pictorial representation of the “O’Driscoll test” that Cook et al2 reported do not represent the actual mechanics of the M-DLS test5 or the DLS test described by Cheung and O’Driscoll1 that have been reported in the literature. We feel that the results presented by Cook et al do reflect their evaluation of the tests as they performed them but do not reflect the results that can be obtained by performing the DLS or M-DLS tests.

We would refer readers to the actual papers describing the DLS and M-DLS tests.1,4,5,7 The methods of performing these tests require the tester to place the scapula in a position of stability, place the arm in a position that reproduces the symptomatic position, and place a compression and shear load on the joint that creates the response. We agree that there is a real challenge in making the clinical diagnosis of a clinically significant SLAP tear, but in ours and others’ clinical experience, this test, performed in the correct manner, can be of significant help in determining the presence of an anatomic labral injury and can aid in the diagnosis of this difficult clinical problem.

body.p: We would like to thank Dr Kibler and Dr O’Driscoll for their thoughtful and insightful comments regarding this Current Concepts review on SLAP injuries.

We acknowledge and recognize the concerns regarding the data as presented by Cook et al and appreciate Dr Kibler and Dr O’Driscoll for bringing this to the attention of the AJSM readership. We agree that while the specificity of any physical examination test for a SLAP injury is limited, the DLS and M-DLS tests can offer some valuable insights in identifying clinically significant lesions that are symptomatic in positions of athletic activity. The key differences that have been highlighted in the technique of the examination are subtle yet critically important to the conclusion.
